Provenance.name: Provenance
Provenance.description: A field containing a DataHarmonizer versioning marker. It is issued by DataHarmonizer when validation is applied to a given row of data.

float.name: float
float.description: A real number that conforms to the xsd:float specification

double.name: double
double.description: A real number that conforms to the xsd:double specification

decimal.name: decimal
decimal.description: A real number with arbitrary precision that conforms to the xsd:decimal specification

time.name: time
time.description: A time object represents a (local) time of day, independent of any particular day
notes: URI is dateTime because OWL reasoners do not work with straight date or time

date.name: date
date.description: a date (year, month and day) in an idealized calendar
notes: URI is dateTime because OWL reasoners don't work with straight date or time

datetime.name: datetime
datetime.description: The combination of a date and time

date_or_datetime.name: date_or_datetime
date_or_datetime.description: Either a date or a datetime

curie.name: curie
comments: in RDF serializations this MUST be expanded to a URI
in non-RDF serializations MAY be serialized as the compact representation

uri.name: uri
comments: in RDF serializations a slot with range of uri is treated as a literal or type xsd:anyURI unless it is an identifier or a reference to an identifier, in which case it is translated directly to a node

objectidentifier.name: objectidentifier
objectidentifier.description: A URI or CURIE that represents an object in the model.
comments: Used for inheritence and type checking

nodeidentifier.name: nodeidentifier
nodeidentifier.description: A URI, CURIE or BNODE that represents a node in a model.

ACOUSTIC_RANGING/GPS.description: Acoustic ranging from a GPS-navigated ship to identify the location of instrumentation on the seafloor.

DVL/LBL.description: Real-time DVL dead-reckoning navigation supplemented with LBL navigation to help constrain fixes to a geographic coordinate system. Errors on the order of 10s (sometimes 100s) of meters are likely in these data.

DVL/LBL/INS.description: Real-time DVL dead-reckoning navigation supplemented with LBL navigation and INS (Inertial Navigation System) navigation.

Object Type.name: Object Type
Object Type.description: Broad characterization of the nature of a sample or specimen.
Object Type.title: Object Type
comments: Provide feedback on additional terms or revisions needed.

User Code.name: User Code
User Code.description: Globally unique IGSN code that will be used as a prefix for IGSNs in the submitted batch template.
User Code.title: User Code
comments: User codes should be unique to an individual or large project managed by a team; avoid creating multiple user codes. If assigning IGSNs in the IGSN column, the user code must match the user code in the IGSNs. For example, if the user specifies IEMEG is the user code, any user-specified IGSNs must begin with IEMEG. If you do not specify the user code to be used, a default user code belonging to the registrant will be used.

Sample Name.name: Sample Name
Sample Name.description: Collector's project-specific sample name, which must be unique for each sample that you are submitting.
Sample Name.title: Sample Name
comments: You can develop a sample ID that has meaning to you and may help in your internal, project sample management.

Other names.name: Other names
Other names.description: Other sample name(s) that have been used in the past.
Other names.title: Other names
comments: Use a semi-colon to delimit multiple names where needed.

IGSN.name: IGSN
IGSN.description: Globally unique and persistent identifier for the sample. Leave blank if you want SESAR to assign the IGSN, which is recommended.
IGSN.title: IGSN
comments: For split samples/subsamples, you can assign your own 1-2 character extensions from the Parent IGSN, and submit your own IGSNs for registering these child samples. This is not required, but is an option if desired. For assigning your own IGSNS, you must use upper-case alpha-numeric characters.

Parent IGSN.name: Parent IGSN
Parent IGSN.description: The larger sample from which a child sample was derived. For example, a core section may be the parent of a series of subsamples or split samples. Parent and child samples are linked in the SESAR catalog. Sibling samples are inferred from parent-child relationships and are linked on the landing page for a sample.
Parent IGSN.title: Parent IGSN
comments: Leave blank if a parent IGSN does not exist.

Collection ID.name: Collection ID
Collection ID.description: A unique identifier for the set of information associated with a collection of samples; collections may be organized around a particular project, data set, field season, region, site, etc.
Collection ID.title: Collection ID
comments: Must be unique within the data package (project-assigned, and does not need to be globally unique). See link to diagram that demonstrates linking related collection, site, event, and sample IDs. A collection identifier can be used to link a set of samples together, and/or to enable efficient entry of metadata that is the same across all samples in a "sample collection."

Event ID.name: Event ID
Event ID.description: A unique identifier for the set of information associated with an Event (something that occurs at a place and time).
Event ID.title: Event ID
comments: Must be unique within the data package (project-assigned, and does not need to be globally unique). See link to diagram that demonstrates linking related collection, site, event, and sample IDs. An event identifier can be used to link a set of samples collected on a specific date, and/or to enable efficient entry of metadata that is the same across these samples.

Location ID.name: Location ID
Location ID.description: A unique identifier for the set of location information. May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.
Location ID.title: Location ID
comments: Must be unique within the data package (project-assigned, and does not need to be globally unique). See link to diagram that demonstrates linking related collection, site, event, and sample IDs. A site identifier can be used to link a set of samples collected from a specific site, and/or to enable efficient entry of metadata that is the same across these samples.

Material.name: Material
Material.description: Material that the sample consists of.
Material.title: Material
comments: Use a semi-colon to delimit multiple materials where needed. Please provide feedback on any other terms needed.

Field name informal classification.name: Field name informal classification
Field name informal classification.title: Field name informal classification
comments: Here you can add additional material classifications that are not in the current SESAR IGSN controlled fields.

Sample Description.name: Sample Description
Sample Description.description: Description of sample features, such as its components, texture, color, shape, treatments, plot ID from which the sample was taken, etc.
Sample Description.title: Sample Description
comments: None

examples.value: Day 223 core section from unheated control plot 1C of a deep soil warming
Filter used for filtered surface water samples

Purpose.name: Purpose
Purpose.description: The scientific purpose for collecting the sample.
Purpose.title: Purpose
comments: Purpose may often be the same across a series/collection of samples; To avoid entering the same information across numerous samples, you can create a separate file with metadata to describe a sample collection, which contains a "collectionID", and any associated metadata fields (e.g. "collectionMethodDescription", "Purpose" "Chief Scientist", etc.).

examples.value: geochemistry and microbiology of soils associated with trees and shrubs

Size.name: Size
Size.description: Size of the registered object, such as the surface area, length of a core, weight, or volume.
Size.title: Size
comments: Must be associated with Size unit.

Size unit.name: Size unit
Size unit.description: Unit for the numerical value provided for ‘size’.
Size unit.title: Size unit
comments: Use any additional unit terms from Units Ontology, and provide feedback.

Filter Size.name: Filter Size
Filter Size.description: Filtering pore size used in sample preparation (filter size value range). Filter size value range.
Filter Size.title: Filter Size
comments: Number range (float-float)

Filter Size Unit.name: Filter Size Unit
Filter Size Unit.title: Filter Size Unit
comments: unit (float-float unit)

Scientific Name.name: Scientific Name
Scientific Name.description: The full scientific name, with authorship and date information if known. When forming part of an Identification, this should be the name in lowest level taxonomic rank that can be determined.
Scientific Name.title: Scientific Name

Sample Remarks.name: Sample Remarks
Sample Remarks.description: Comments or notes about the sample.
Sample Remarks.title: Sample Remarks
comments: You can include weather descriptions here, if relevant.

Collector Chief Scientist.name: Collector Chief Scientist
Collector Chief Scientist.description: Name of the person(s) who collected the sample.
Collector Chief Scientist.title: Collector Chief Scientist
comments: You can enter multiple collectors/sampling team for large sampling efforts, separated with a semi-colon. If the collector(s) of the sample(s) is/are not known, enter name of the person responsible for the sample

Collection Date.name: Collection Date
Collection Date.description: Date when the sample was collected.
Collection Date.title: Collection Date
comments: All dates and times must be reported in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) and follow the ISO 8601 standard (RFC 3339). Temporal data using different standards can be provided as a separate variable (column) in addition to UTC format; YYYY-MM-DD

Collection Time.name: Collection Time
Collection Time.description: Time when the sample was collected.
Collection Time.title: Collection Time
comments: All dates and times must be reported in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) and follow the ISO 8601 standard (RFC 3339). Temporal data using different standards can be provided as a separate variable (column) in addition to UTC format; HH:MM:SSZ

Collection Method Description.name: Collection Method Description
Collection Method Description.description: Description of the collection method for the sample. Include any important terms and details for potential users to understand how your sample was collected.
Collection Method Description.title: Collection Method Description
comments: Collection methods may often be the same across a series/collection of samples; there are two options for providing collection method details at a higher level. Option 1 -  Create a separate file with metadata to describe a sample collection, which contains a "collectionID", and any associated metadata fields (e.g. "collectionMethodDescription", "Purpose", "Chief Scientist", etc.). Option 2 - Create a methods file, with a series of methods descriptions that are each associated with a "methodID" and an associated "methodDescription."

examples.value: Example 1) Collect soil samples from top 10 cm using 2-3 cores from with meadow plot or under the bulk of tree/shrub canopies.
Example 3) Pumped water at specific depths using tubing connected to CTD.

Sample Processing.name: Sample Processing
Sample Processing.description: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from the environment. Can provide a list of preparations and preservation methods for the sample.
Sample Processing.title: Sample Processing
comments: Sample processing may often be the same across a series/collection of samples. To avoid entering the same information across numerous samples, you can create a separate file with metadata to describe a sample collection, which contains a "collectionID", and any associated metadata fields (e.g. "sampleProcessing", "collectionMethodDescription", "Purpose", "Chief Scientist", etc.). Separate multiple sample processing methods with a semi-colon.

Field Program or Project Name.name: Field Program or Project Name
Field Program or Project Name.description: Enter the name of the DOE project to associate with this/these sample(s).
Field Program or Project Name.title: Field Program or Project Name
comments: Required at dataset level, but want to associate with samples for data search and integration. Project details may often be the same across a series/collection of samples; To avoid entering the same information across numerous samples, you can create a separate file with metadata to describe a project or sample collection, which contains a "collectionID" or "Field Program/Cruise", and any associated metadata fields (e.g. "Collection Method Description", "Purpose", "Chief Scientist"...

Latitude Coordinate system WGS 84.name: Latitude Coordinate system WGS 84
Latitude Coordinate system WGS 84.description: Latitude of the location where the sample was collected, entered in decimal degrees. Negative values for South latitudes.
Latitude Coordinate system WGS 84.title: Latitude Coordinate system WGS 84
comments: Decimal degrees, coordinate system is WGS 84. Please supply no more than 6 decimal places (meter scale resolution) in the actual number (not just display format.) No letters are allowed.

Longitude Coordinate system WGS 84.name: Longitude Coordinate system WGS 84
Longitude Coordinate system WGS 84.description: Longitude of the location where the sample was collected. Negative values for ‘West’ longitudes.
Longitude Coordinate system WGS 84.title: Longitude Coordinate system WGS 84
comments: Decimal degrees, coordinate system is WGS 84. Please supply no more than 6 decimal places (meter scale resolution) in the actual number (not just display format.) No letters are allowed.

Navigation Type.name: Navigation Type
Navigation Type.description: Type of geolocation instrument used to obtain geographic coordinates.
Navigation Type.title: Navigation Type
comments: Provide feedback on additional terms needed.

Location Description.name: Location Description
Location Description.description: Free text description of the location.
Location Description.title: Location Description
comments: You can also include details here about the location type, e.g. whether it is an absolute or reference location, plot ID and description.

examples.value: 300 year old low-land tropical rainforest in Parque Natural San Lorenzo

Country.name: Country
Country.description: Country where the sample was collected.
Country.title: Country
comments: Use SESAR list, but may change controlled list to GAZ ontology.

Elevation start.name: Elevation start
Elevation start.description: Elevation at which a sample was collected. Minimum elevation value, if elevation taken over a range.
Elevation start.title: Elevation start
comments: Provide elevation in meters where possible.

Elevation end.name: Elevation end
Elevation end.description: Maximum elevation at which a sample was collected, if elevation was taken over a range.
Elevation end.title: Elevation end
comments: Leave blank if elevation is a single value and not range. Provide elevation in meters where possible.

Elevation unit.name: Elevation unit
Elevation unit.description: Unit that elevation start and/or end are provided in.
Elevation unit.title: Elevation unit
comments: Recommend meters. This will be removed when elevation field is changed to specify meters.

Minimum Depth in Meters.name: Minimum Depth in Meters
Minimum Depth in Meters.description: Depth, or minimum depth (if taken over a range) at which a sample was collected, below ground or under water.
Minimum Depth in Meters.title: Minimum Depth in Meters
comments: Recommend using meters.

Maximum Depth in Meters.name: Maximum Depth in Meters
Maximum Depth in Meters.description: Maximum depth at which a sample was collected, below ground or under water.
Maximum Depth in Meters.title: Maximum Depth in Meters
comments: Recommend using meters.

Depth scale.name: Depth scale
Depth scale.description: Unit in which the depth is provided, should be meters.
Depth scale.title: Depth scale
comments: This field will be deleted when we change the depth field to be required in meters.

Minimum Distance above Surface in Meters.name: Minimum Distance above Surface in Meters
Minimum Distance above Surface in Meters.description: Minimum height above the ground surface, in meters. If no range of values collected, provide height measurement here.
Minimum Distance above Surface in Meters.title: Minimum Distance above Surface in Meters
comments: Recommend using meters.

Maximum Distance above Surface in Meters.name: Maximum Distance above Surface in Meters
Maximum Distance above Surface in Meters.description: Maximum height above the ground surface, in meters.
Maximum Distance above Surface in Meters.title: Maximum Distance above Surface in Meters
comments: Recommend using meters.

Physiographic feature.name: Physiographic feature
Physiographic feature.description: Entity or entities which are in your sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen.
Physiographic feature.title: Physiographic feature
comments: Terms from Environment Ontology (ENVO). Provide the appropriate term and ENVO identifier - see examples below. Choose environmental context that is a smaller spatial grain than your entry for biome. Delimit multiple values using semi-colon. If needed, request new terms on the ENVO tracker, identified here.

examples.value: For annotating a pooled sample taken from various vegetation layers in a forest, consider - canopy [ENVO:00000047]; herb and fern layer [ENVO:01000337]; litter layer [ENVO:01000338]; understory [01000335]; shrub layer [ENVO:01000336].

Biome.name: Biome
Biome.description: Major environmental system your sample or specimen came from. The systems identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. were you in the desert or a rainforest?).
Biome.title: Biome
comments: Terms from Environment Ontology (ENVO). Provide the appropriate term and ENVO identifier - see examples below. We recommend using subclasses of ENVO’s biome class. Use a semi-colon to delimit multiple biomes where needed. If needed, request new terms on the ENVO tracker, identified here.

examples.value: tropical moist broadleaf forest biome [ENVO:01000228]; estuarine biome [ENVO:01000020]

Release Date.name: Release Date
Release Date.description: Date when sample metadata should be publicly accessible and searchable. If null, defaults to date of registration in SESAR (recommended).
Release Date.title: Release Date
comments: SESAR recommends that sample metadata become public within 2 years of sample registration; YYYY-MM-DD format

Current Archive.name: Current Archive
Current Archive.description: Name of institution, museum, or repository where the sample is currently stored.
Current Archive.title: Current Archive
comments: Only applies to physical samples that are archived in a collection for some period of time.

examples.value: Geosciences and Environmental Change Science Center

Current Archive Contact.name: Current Archive Contact
Current Archive Contact.description: Address and/or email of the person who should be contacted for information about or access to the sample.
Current Archive Contact.title: Current Archive Contact
comments: Email is not mandatory, but helps with communication about samples.

Minimum Distance above Surface in Meters.name: Minimum Distance above Surface in Meters

Maximum Distance above Surface in Meters.name: Maximum Distance above Surface in Meters
